Award.AwardTitle: Engaging Latino Audiences in Informal Science Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Engaging Latinos in Informal Science Education is designed to address the low participation rate of Latino youth and adults in activities conducted by parks, refuges, nature centers, and other informal science education venues. The project objectives are to expand upon existing studies that attempt to identify barriers to Latino participation, work with communities to identify the tools needed to overcome barriers, and utilize the tools in established programs. Surveys and interviews conducted with Latino communities are designed to identify key measures that will improve participation in informal learning programs which are then implemented in the International Migratory Bird Day (IMBD) program. Park Flight international interns from Mexico, Central America, the Caribbean, and the US will work in Latino communities near seven sites that host annual IMBD. Deliverables include a comprehensive technical report resulting from the analysis of surveys and a toolkit to promote the involvement of Latino communities in informal science education. The multi-stage evaluation includes the annual evaluation of participation levels at seven treatment and five control sites, pilot testing of the key strategies for family involvement identified in the survey results, and formative evaluation of the project toolkit. Project partners are the National Park (NPS) Service, NPS Park Flight Migratory Bird Program, Colorado State University, Rocky Mountain Bird Observatory, PRBO Conservation Services, and six national parks. Strategic impact will be realized through the development and national dissemination of the project toolkit to almost 1000 partner offices across the US.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although the issue of diversity and concerns about the failure to engage Latino audiences in informal science learning (ISL) are persistent, few organizations have expanded their research beyond visitation to quantify participation rates of diverse audiences in their public programs or to examine the characteristics of the individuals and groups that do participate in these programs. In 2009, Environment for the Americas, a non-profit education organization, sought to address the lack of data available by conducting baseline surveys at seven nature-based public events held in communities and national and state parks in Colorado, New Mexico, Washington, California, New Jersey, and New York. Our goal was to understand influences over Latino participation in informal science education programs and events at natural areas and in communities. We conducted surveys across the country at sites located near cities and towns with established Latino populations. Additionally, we gathered information about the characteristics of Latino participants, including the size of their group, the distance traveled to the site, and prior experience with the study sites and examined if these factors differed from non-Latino participants. The baseline was intended to examine if any obvious geographic or demographic factors were important influences. Subsequent surveys and research gathered more detailed data on the barriers to participation and the mechanisms to address them.
This study was accomplished in several phases. The first phase established an advisory board comprised of predominately Latino science educators. The advisory board and evaluators developed a survey instrument (called Community Survey) that was used in 1,000 face-to-face interviews with self-identifying Latino adults residing near the 6 study sites. The surveys collected information on income, level of education, attitudes toward nature and nature-based programs, logistical barriers to participating in programs at study sites, language preferences, country of origin, and ways to market to this audience. During this phase, base line information was gathered on participants of science programs at the study and control sites through the Participant Surveys. 
In the second phase, bilingual, Latino personnel were hired and trained in environmental education, diversity outreach, and public affairs at the study sites. A Latino engagement plan was developed for each site taking into account the results of the Community Surveys. Environmental education programs were offered at schools, community based organizations, and other groups that serve Latino families. Bilingual marketing was done in social media platforms, radio, television, and print media. Outreach activity booths promoting the study sites, science programs, and migratory bird conservation were held at large cultural public events. Participant Surveys were conducted at the science programs to gauge the effectiveness of the engagement initiatives. The engagement plan was implemented in year 2 and 3 of the study. 
In the final phase, we summarized our research and findings and created an online resource, the Connecting Cultures Toolkit, with case studies, data findings, templates, concrete tips and examples, and bilingual teaching materials.
Our study is the only one (of which we are aware) that studies the challenges of diversity at sites across the United States that represent different Latina/o groups, countries of origin,
generations in the United States, language preferences, and other factors that may impact participation in informal science education. Other studies tend to be local and address the challenges and needs of single sites.
